title: 106_hr2309
content: The Act may be cited as the "Independent Medical Review Act of 1999" and includes special rules for group health plans. Section 503 of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to include special rules for group health plans, requiring claims procedures to notify participants of their right to appeal adverse determinations to a utilization review agent. The amended Section 503 of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 includes rules for group health plans, requiring notification to participants of their right to appeal adverse determinations to a utilization review agent and an independent review organization. The procedures for appealing to an independent review organization must also be provided. The amended Section 503 of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 mandates notification to participants of their right to appeal adverse determinations to an independent review organization, including procedures for immediate review for life-threatening conditions and fair, de novo determination of medical necessity. The amended Section 503 of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 requires notification to participants of their right to appeal adverse determinations to an independent review organization. The procedures for appeals must be reasonable and include immediate review for life-threatening conditions and fair, de novo determination of medical necessity. The employee benefit plan allows participants to appeal denied claims to a utilization review agent. Appeals can be made orally or in writing, and the agent must respond within 5 working days. The health care provider can appeal an adverse determination orally or in writing. The utilization review agent must acknowledge receipt of the appeal within 5 working days and provide a list of required documents. If the appeal is made orally, a one-page appeal form will be sent by the agent. The utilization review agent must send a one-page appeal form to the appealing party in cases of oral appeals of adverse determinations. Appeal decisions will be made by a physician, but can be reviewed by a health care provider of the same specialty if good cause is provided within 10 working days of denial. The health care provider must provide good cause in writing for a specialty review of denied cases, which must be completed within 15 working days. An expedited appeal process is available for emergency care denials and life-threatening conditions. An expedited appeal procedure must be available for emergency care denials, life-threatening conditions, and denials of continued stays for hospitalized patients. The appeal must be reviewed by a healthcare provider of the same specialty within a specified time frame based on the medical urgency. The appeal process for adverse determinations must be completed within one working day based on medical urgency. The utilization review agent must issue a response letter after seeking review of the appeal. The utilization review agent must issue a response letter to the appealing party explaining the resolution of the appeal, including specific medical reasons and clinical basis for the decision. The utilization review agent must provide written notification of the appeal determination within 30 days. If an appeal is denied, the participant can seek independent review of the adverse determination. Independent review of adverse determinations can be sought from an independent review organization if an appeal is denied by a utilization review agent. The process ensures a timely response by the independent review organization. Independent review of adverse determinations under this subsection is conducted by an independent review organization, ensuring timely responses, confidentiality of medical records, independence of healthcare providers, and timely notice to participants. Independent review of adverse determinations is conducted by an independent review organization, with timely notice to participants of the results and clinical basis for the determination. The utilization review agent must provide relevant medical records and documents to the independent review organization within 3 business days of receiving a request for review of an adverse determination. The utilization review agent must provide medical records, documents, and written notification to the independent review organization for review of an adverse determination. The utilization review agent must provide medical records, documents, and written notification to the independent review organization for review of an adverse determination, including clinical basis, documentation submitted, and list of relevant healthcare providers. The independent review organization must make a determination within 15 days of receiving necessary information from relevant healthcare providers. The independent review organization must make a determination within 15 days of receiving necessary information for non-life-threatening conditions, or within 20 days of receiving the request for determination. The independent review organization must make a determination within 5 days for life-threatening conditions, or within 8 days after receiving necessary information. The independent review organization must make a determination within 5 days for life-threatening conditions or within 8 days of receiving the necessary information, and must be certified by the Secretary to be considered an independent review organization. To be certified as an independent review organization, an organization must submit an annual application to the Secretary including specific information. Publicly held organizations must also provide the names of each applicant. The application for certification as an independent review organization must include details such as the names of stockholders owning more than 5 percent, the names and types of affiliated corporations, and the extent of control or affiliation. The application for certification as an independent review organization must include details such as the names of stockholders owning more than 5 percent, affiliated corporations, and relationships with individuals holding bonds exceeding $100,000, as well as biographical information of directors, officers, and executives. The application for certification as an independent review organization requires disclosing relationships of directors, officers, and executives with health insurance providers, HMOs, utilization review agents, nonprofit health corporations, and payors. The application for certification as an independent review organization requires disclosing relationships with various entities, including health insurance providers, HMOs, utilization review agents, nonprofit health corporations, payors, health care providers, and related groups. The application also requires disclosing the percentage of anticipated revenues from reviews conducted under this subsection. The application for certification as an independent review organization requires disclosing relationships with various entities and the percentage of anticipated revenues from reviews conducted under this subsection. It also includes details on the areas of expertise of health care professionals and the procedures used for review determinations. The independent review organization must disclose relationships and revenue sources. Their determination is final and binding on the plan, with the option for vacation or modification. The determination by an independent review entity is final and may be vacated or modified by a court. An independent review organization must not be owned or controlled by a payor or a trade association. An independent review organization must not be owned or controlled by a payor or a trade association and is not liable for damages arising from its determination. The term 'adverse determination' refers to a decision by a group health plan or utilization review agent that certain health care services are not medically necessary. The term 'health care provider' includes individuals delivering health care services in a State. The term 'health care provider' includes individuals and entities delivering health care services in a State, required to be licensed or certified by State law. Entities delivering health care services in a State must be licensed or certified by State law. Life-threatening condition is defined as a medical condition where death or serious injury is likely without intervention. Payor refers to entities responsible for payment. The term 'life-threatening condition' refers to a disease or medical condition where death or serious bodily injury is likely without intervention. 'Payor' includes insurers, preferred provider organizations, self-insurance plans, and entities providing health benefits. The term 'utilization review agent' refers to an entity that conducts utilization review for employers, payors, or administrators. 'Working day' is defined as a weekday excluding legal holidays.
